title: Machine Learning: The High Interest Credit Card of Technical Debt – Google Research

last_post.content:
All the hype about souped up developer productivity using LLMs for coding reminds me of the original title of this 2014 paper, before it was milquetoasted in 2015 acceptance.

LLMs can help you rapidly acquire semi-plagiarized fragments of well-traveled code instead of using a quality library with vision of the problem domain. Might be great for KPIs, but this debt will come back to bite you, unless you're already gone. Will be painful for orgs to adapt.
https://research.google/pubs/pub43146/

title: How the Computer Got Its Revenge on the Soviet Union - Nautilus

last_post.content: “The results of top-down computerization were devastating. New computer systems accumulated ever-increasing amounts of raw data and generated terrifying heaps of paperwork. In the early 1970s, roughly 4 billion documents per year circulated through the Soviet economy. By the mid-1980s, after Herculean efforts to computerize the bureaucratic apparatus, this figure rose by a factor of 200 to about 800 billion documents, or 3,000 documents for every Soviet citizen.” https://nautil.us/how-the-computer-got-its-revenge-on-the-soviet-union-235368/

In May 1944 he was deported to Auschwitz and murdered in the gas chamber.

In this age of corporate algorithms, whatever happened to the idea of *personal* Internet User Agents?

The original idea was software you ran yourself, which crawled the Internet to find things for you. (This is a simplification, of course.)

And that idea survives to this day in the form of the User Agent String used for HTTP content negotiation. But, so far as I know, only corporate search bots and web browsers still have user agent strings.

> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_agent

TIL: Bayesian persuasion/manipulation.

An example: Bayesian judge calls guilty when P(guilty) > 0.5, they get 1 utility for correct verdict, 0 for incorrect. A priori P(guilty) = 0.3 - this is the correct population prevalence.

I get to choose how investigation is conducted. By choosing to collect binary information X \in {0,1}, such that P(X = 0 | innocent) = 4/7 and P(X = 0| guilty) = 0 the judge will convict in 60% of the cases (without deception!).

Ref: https://web.stanford.edu/~gentzkow/research/BayesianPersuasion.pdf 1/3

title: Black Artists Helped Build Country Music—And Then It Left Them Behind

last_post.content:
So guess where country music comes from?

https://time.com/5673476/ken-burns-country-music-black-artists/

Black cowboys were also expected to cook. If New Orleans food is what happens when French food meets West African food, then original Texas barbecue is what happens when German and Czech food meets African food.

But where did all the Black cowboys go then? Yes, some Black cowboys would eventually try to establish their own ranches, but white ranchers would often accuse them of cattle theft, then lynch them and steal their stuff.

title: Mastodon is dead in the water - HackerNoon.com - Medium

last_post.content:
Interesting reading "retro" reviews of #Mastodon from 2017.

"Mastodon is Dead in the Water..."

Notice how amazed at 18K users signing up a week then, which we are doing *per day *now on quiet weeks, or per half-hour when Elon does something dumb. And how mastodon.social had 40K users then.

I actually don't disagree with many of his suggestions for fixes, but interesting to see how many of these have been largely or fully solved: account portability being a biggie.

https://medium.com/hackernoon/mastodon-is-dead-in-the-water-888c10e8abb1
